abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is satisfactory insofar
            as the project has largely met, and in some cases, surpassed
            specific targets with respect to increasing access to
            primary education--especially for girls, improving equity,
            developing learning inputs--such as teacher training and
            instructional materials, and establishing partnerships with
            nongovernmental organizations to mobilize communities. Based
            on assessing the government's commitment to sustain
            proven project gains, and as evidenced by low allocations to
            current low-salary recurrent and developmental budgets and
            structural arrangements to ensure a smooth transition to a
            non-project mode of operation in mainstream institutions, it
            is unlikely that most of the project's gains will be
            sustainable in the short to medium-term. World Bank
            performance is adjudged satisfactory while Borrower
            performance is rated unsatisfactory. Some lessons for the
            Bank include avoiding complex project designs, incorporating
            an agreed exit strategy into project design, ensuring the
            borrower's ownership of project design, assessing
            procurement capacity properly, addressing financial
            management in the project design, setting up a declining
            scale allowing the borrower to gradually absorb recurrent
            liabilities, ensuring continuity in supervision teams,
            backing supervision missions with appropriate budgets,
            staffing managerial and technical units with qualified
            personnel, and involving the community and NGOs in designing
            and implementing interventions.
